questions.subject: Physics
questions.text: What is the SI unit of force?
questions.explanation: Force is defined as mass times acceleration. The SI unit of force is Newton (N), named after Sir Isaac Newton. It is derived as 1 N = 1 kg·m/s².

questions.subject: Physics
questions.text: Which of the following is a scalar quantity?
questions.explanation: A scalar quantity has only magnitude and no direction. Temperature is a scalar quantity as it only indicates magnitude (e.g., 25°C), while velocity, acceleration, and force are vector quantities as they have both magnitude and direction.

questions.subject: Physics
questions.text: Which law states that an object at rest stays at rest unless acted upon by an external force?
questions.explanation: Newton’s First Law, also known as the Law of Inertia, states that an object at rest stays at rest and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and direction unless acted upon by an external force.

questions.subject: Physics
questions.text: What is the dimensional formula of work?
questions.explanation: Work is defined as force times distance. Force has the dimensional formula [MLT⁻²], and distance has the dimensional formula [L]. Therefore, the dimensional formula of work is [MLT⁻²] × [L] = [ML²T⁻²].

questions.subject: Physics
questions.text: A convex lens forms a real, inverted image when the object is placed:
options: Between the lens and the focus
questions.explanation: A convex lens forms a real and inverted image when the object is placed beyond the focal point. When the object is at twice the focal length (2F), the image is also real, inverted, and formed at 2F on the other side of the lens.

questions.subject: Physics
questions.text: Which of the following waves does not require a medium to propagate?
questions.explanation: Electromagnetic waves, such as light and radio waves, can travel through a vacuum and do not require a medium for propagation. Sound waves, water waves, and seismic waves are mechanical waves that require a medium (air, water, or earth) to propagate.

questions.subject: Physics
questions.text: The escape velocity from Earth is approximately:
questions.explanation: Escape velocity is the minimum speed needed for an object to escape Earth's gravitational pull without further propulsion. For Earth, this value is approximately 11.2 km/s, derived from the formula v = √(2GM/R), where G is the gravitational constant, M is Earth's mass, and R is Earth's radius.

questions.subject: Physics
questions.text: Which of the following statements about friction is correct?
options: Static friction is always less than kinetic friction
Friction depends on the nature of surfaces in contact
Friction acts in the direction of motion
questions.explanation: Friction depends on the nature of the surfaces in contact (e.g., rough or smooth) and the normal force between them. The other statements are incorrect: friction can be desirable (e.g., for walking), static friction is typically greater than kinetic friction, and friction acts opposite to the direction of motion.

questions.subject: Physics
questions.text: Which thermodynamic process occurs at constant pressure?
questions.explanation: An isobaric process is one that occurs at constant pressure. Isothermal processes occur at constant temperature, adiabatic processes involve no heat transfer, and isochoric processes occur at constant volume.

questions.subject: Physics
questions.text: The moment of inertia of a solid sphere rotating about its diameter is given by:
questions.explanation: The moment of inertia of a solid sphere about its diameter is given by I = (2/5)MR², where M is the mass and R is the radius. This is derived from the standard formula for a solid sphere using the perpendicular axis theorem and integration.

questions.subject: Physics
questions.text: In an AC circuit, the power factor is given by:
questions.explanation: The power factor in an AC circuit is defined as cos θ, where θ is the phase angle between the voltage and current. It represents the fraction of electrical power that is converted into useful work.

questions.subject: Physics
questions.text: Which of the following particles has the least mass?
questions.explanation: The electron has the least mass among the given options. Its mass is approximately 9.11 × 10⁻³¹ kg, while the proton and neutron have masses around 1.67 × 10⁻²⁷ kg, and an alpha particle (helium nucleus) has a mass roughly four times that of a proton.

questions.subject: Physics
questions.text: Which type of mirror is used in car rearview mirrors?
questions.explanation: Convex mirrors are used in car rearview mirrors because they provide a wider field of view and form virtual, upright, and diminished images, allowing drivers to see more area behind them.

questions.subject: Physics
questions.text: Which physical quantity is conserved in an elastic collision?
questions.explanation: In an elastic collision, both momentum and kinetic energy are conserved. Momentum is always conserved in collisions (as per the law of conservation of momentum), and in elastic collisions, kinetic energy is also conserved because there is no loss of energy to heat or deformation.

questions.subject: Physics
questions.text: The unit of resistivity in SI is:
questions.explanation: Resistivity (ρ) is defined as the resistance of a material per unit length and cross-sectional area. Its SI unit is ohm-meter (Ω·m), derived from the formula ρ = R(A/L), where R is resistance (ohm), A is area (m²), and L is length (m).

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.text: Water is a compound composed of hydrogen and oxygen.
questions.explanation: Water (H₂O) is indeed a compound composed of two hydrogen atoms bonded to one oxygen atom through covalent bonds. It is not an element or a mixture, making the statement true.

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a noble gas?
questions.explanation: Noble gases are elements in Group 18 of the periodic table, known for their low reactivity due to a full valence electron shell. Helium is a noble gas, while oxygen, nitrogen, and chlorine are not.

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.text: Which law states that the total pressure of a mixture of gases is equal to the sum of the partial pressures of individual gases?
questions.explanation: Dalton’s Law of Partial Pressures states that in a mixture of non-reacting gases, the total pressure is the sum of the partial pressures of each gas. Boyle’s Law relates pressure and volume, Charles’s Law relates volume and temperature, and Avogadro’s Law relates volume and the number of moles.

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.text: What is the oxidation state of sulfur in H₂SO₄?
questions.explanation: To find the oxidation state of sulfur in H₂SO₄, we set up the equation: 2(+1) + x + 4(-2) = 0 (since the molecule is neutral). Solving for x: 2 + x - 8 = 0, x = +6. Thus, the oxidation state of sulfur is +6.

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a strong acid?
questions.explanation: Hydrochloric acid (HCl) is a strong acid because it completely dissociates in water into H⁺ and Cl⁻ ions. Acetic acid, carbonic acid, and phosphoric acid are weak acids as they only partially dissociate in water.

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.text: The Aufbau principle states that:
options: Electrons fill higher energy orbitals first
Electrons fill lower energy orbitals first
Electrons pair up in an orbital before filling another
Each orbital can hold only one electron
questions.explanation: The Aufbau principle states that electrons occupy the lowest energy orbitals available before filling higher energy orbitals. For example, the 1s orbital fills before 2s, and 2s before 2p.

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.text: What type of bond exists in NaCl?
questions.explanation: NaCl (sodium chloride) consists of an ionic bond, formed by the transfer of an electron from sodium (Na) to chlorine (Cl), resulting in Na⁺ and Cl⁻ ions that are held together by electrostatic attraction.

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.text: Which of the following elements has the highest electronegativity?
questions.explanation: Electronegativity measures an element’s ability to attract electrons in a bond. Fluorine has the highest electronegativity in the periodic table (value of 4.0 on the Pauling scale), followed by oxygen (3.5), chlorine (3.0), and nitrogen (3.0).

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.text: What is the hybridization of carbon in methane (CH₄)?
questions.explanation: In methane (CH₄), carbon forms four single bonds with hydrogen atoms, arranged tetrahedrally. This requires four equivalent orbitals, achieved through sp³ hybridization, where one s and three p orbitals mix to form four sp³ hybrid orbitals.

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.text: Which of the following is an example of an endothermic reaction?
options: Dissolution of ammonium chloride in water
questions.explanation: An endothermic reaction absorbs heat from the surroundings. Dissolving ammonium chloride in water is endothermic as it absorbs heat, causing the solution to cool. Burning of wood, condensation, and respiration are exothermic as they release heat.

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.text: Which of the following compounds does NOT exhibit hydrogen bonding?
questions.explanation: Hydrogen bonding occurs when a hydrogen atom is bonded to a highly electronegative atom (like O, N, or F) and interacts with another electronegative atom. CH₄ (methane) does not exhibit hydrogen bonding because carbon is not sufficiently electronegative, unlike H₂O, NH₃, and HF.

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.text: What is the main product when ethanol is oxidized?
questions.explanation: When ethanol (C₂H₅OH) is oxidized, it first forms acetaldehyde (CH₃CHO) with mild oxidation (e.g., using PCC), and with strong oxidation (e.g., using KMnO₄ or K₂Cr₂O₇), it forms acetic acid (CH₃COOH). Methanol, formaldehyde, and acetone are not the main products.

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.text: Which of the following polymers is an example of a condensation polymer?
questions.explanation: Condensation polymers form with the loss of a small molecule (like water) during polymerization. Nylon is a condensation polymer formed from diamines and dicarboxylic acids, releasing water. Polyethylene, polystyrene, and Teflon are addition polymers, formed without losing a small molecule.

questions.subject: Chemistry
questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a transition metal?
questions.explanation: Transition metals are elements in the d-block of the periodic table that can form multiple oxidation states and often form colored compounds. Copper (Cu) is a transition metal, while calcium, magnesium, and sodium are not (they are s-block elements).

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.text: What is the derivative of sin(x)?
questions.explanation: The derivative of sin(x) with respect to x is cos(x). This is a standard result in calculus, derived from the limit definition of the derivative or using the chain rule with trigonometric identities.

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.text: What is the sum of the first n natural numbers?
questions.explanation: The sum of the first n natural numbers (1 + 2 + ... + n) is given by the formula n(n+1)/2. This can be derived using the arithmetic series formula or by pairing numbers (e.g., 1+n, 2+(n-1), etc.).

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.text: The roots of the quadratic equation ax² + bx + c = 0 are given by:
questions.explanation: The roots of the quadratic equation ax² + bx + c = 0 are given by the quadratic formula: x = [-b ± √(b²-4ac)]/(2a). This formula is derived by completing the square.

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.text: What is the integral of e^x?
questions.explanation: The integral of e^x with respect to x is e^x + C, where C is the constant of integration. This is because the derivative of e^x is e^x, making e^x its own antiderivative.

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.text: What is the value of cos(0°)?
questions.explanation: The value of cos(0°) is 1. This can be understood from the unit circle, where at 0°, the x-coordinate (which represents cos θ) is 1.

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.text: What is the equation of a circle with center (h, k) and radius r?
questions.explanation: The standard equation of a circle with center (h, k) and radius r is (x-h)² + (y-k)² = r². This equation represents all points (x, y) that are at a distance r from the center (h, k).

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.text: If the determinant of a 3x3 matrix is zero, then the system of equations it represents is:
options: Consistent and has a unique solution
Consistent and has infinitely many solutions
questions.explanation: If the determinant of a 3x3 matrix is zero, the matrix is singular (non-invertible), meaning the system of equations it represents either has infinitely many solutions (if consistent) or no solution (if inconsistent). Typically, it implies infinitely many solutions in standard contexts.

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.text: What is the value of logₐ(a^x)?
questions.explanation: Using the logarithm property logₐ(a^x) = x·logₐ(a), and since logₐ(a) = 1 (because a¹ = a), we get logₐ(a^x) = x·1 = x.

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.text: The probability of getting a sum of 7 when rolling two fair six-sided dice is:
questions.explanation: When rolling two dice, there are 36 possible outcomes (6×6). The combinations that sum to 7 are (1,6), (2,5), (3,4), (4,3), (5,2), (6,1), which are 6 outcomes. Thus, the probability is 6/36 = 1/6.

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.text: Which function is always increasing for all real x?
questions.explanation: A function is always increasing if its derivative is always positive. The derivative of e^x is e^x, which is always positive for all x, so e^x is always increasing. In contrast, x² decreases for x < 0, and sin(x) and cos(x) oscillate.

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.text: What is the area under the standard normal curve from -∞ to ∞?
questions.explanation: The standard normal curve (mean 0, standard deviation 1) is a probability density function, and the total area under it from -∞ to ∞ is 1, representing the total probability.

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.text: If A is a square matrix, then A⁻¹ exists if and only if:
questions.explanation: A square matrix A has an inverse (A⁻¹) if and only if its determinant is non-zero (det(A) ≠ 0). If det(A) = 0, the matrix is singular and has no inverse.

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.text: Which of the following is a valid binomial expansion for (x+y)³?
questions.explanation: Using the binomial theorem, (x+y)³ = x³ + 3x²y + 3xy² + y³. The coefficients are given by the binomial coefficients: 1, 3, 3, 1.

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.text: The value of ∫ 1/(1+x²) dx is:
questions.explanation: The integral ∫ 1/(1+x²) dx is a standard form and equals tan⁻¹(x) + C. This can be derived using the substitution x = tan(θ) or by recognizing it as the derivative of tan⁻¹(x).

questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.text: What is the sum of the interior angles of a hexagon?
questions.explanation: The sum of the interior angles of a polygon with n sides is (n-2)×180°. For a hexagon (n=6), the sum is (6-2)×180° = 4×180° = 720°.

questions.subject: Biology
questions.text: Which organelle is known as the powerhouse of the cell?
questions.explanation: The mitochondria is known as the powerhouse of the cell because it produces ATP (adenosine triphosphate), the cell's main energy currency, through cellular respiration.

questions.subject: Biology
questions.text: Which biomolecule is the primary source of energy for living organisms?
questions.explanation: Carbohydrates serve as the primary source of energy, as they are quickly broken down into glucose for cellular respiration.

questions.subject: Biology
questions.text: Which of the following is a structural protein found in connective tissues?
questions.explanation: Collagen is a major structural protein found in connective tissues like tendons, ligaments, and skin.

questions.subject: Biology
questions.text: Which plant hormone is responsible for cell elongation and growth?
questions.explanation: Auxins promote cell elongation and are involved in phototropism and root development.

questions.subject: Biology
questions.text: What is the primary function of the large intestine?
questions.explanation: The large intestine absorbs water and electrolytes and forms solid waste (feces) for excretion.

questions.subject: Biology
questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of prokaryotic cells?
questions.explanation: Prokaryotic cells lack a nuclear membrane and have circular DNA, unlike eukaryotic cells which have linear DNA.

questions.subject: Biology
questions.text: Which part of the brain is responsible for balance and coordination?
questions.explanation: The cerebellum is responsible for coordinating voluntary movements and maintaining balance and posture.

questions.subject: Biology
questions.text: What is the main function of hemoglobin in red blood cells?
questions.explanation: Hemoglobin binds to oxygen in the lungs and transports it to tissues throughout the body.

questions.subject: Biology
questions.text: Which type of RNA carries amino acids to the ribosome during protein synthesis?
questions.explanation: Transfer RNA (tRNA) carries specific amino acids to the ribosome, facilitating the process of translation in protein synthesis.

questions.subject: Biology
questions.text: Which vitamin is essential for blood clotting?
questions.explanation: Vitamin K is essential for synthesizing clotting factors in the blood, helping to prevent excessive bleeding.

questions.subject: Engineering Mathematics
questions.text: What is the value of ∫(0 to π) sin(x) dx?
questions.explanation: The integral ∫(0 to π) sin(x) dx represents the area under the curve of sin(x) from 0 to π. The antiderivative of sin(x) is -cos(x). Evaluating at the limits: [-cos(π)] - [-cos(0)] = [-(-1)] - [-1] = 1 + 1 = 2.

questions.subject: General Studies
questions.text: Who was the first Prime Minister of India?
questions.explanation: Jawaharlal Nehru was the first Prime Minister of India, serving from 1947 until his death in 1964. Mahatma Gandhi was a freedom fighter but never held office, Sardar Patel was the first Deputy Prime Minister, and Indira Gandhi was a later Prime Minister.
